title: Amos Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Amos chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Amos Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Amos Chapter 8.

questions.question: What did the Lord GOD show Amos in a vision according to Amos 8:1?
options: A basket of summer fruit
A burning bush
A pillar of fire
A flowing river
questions.correctAnswer: A basket of summer fruit
questions.explanation: Amos 8:1 states that the Lord GOD showed Amos a basket of summer fruit.

questions.question: According to Amos 8:2, what did the Lord say about the people of Israel?
options: The end is come upon my people of Israel
They will be victorious
They shall be blessed forever
They will build a great temple
questions.correctAnswer: The end is come upon my people of Israel
questions.explanation: In Amos 8:2, the Lord declares that the end has come upon His people of Israel and He will not pass by them anymore.

questions.question: What will the songs of the temple become on that day, as stated in Amos 8:3?
options: Howlings
Joyful praises
Silent prayers
Songs of victory
questions.correctAnswer: Howlings
questions.explanation: Amos 8:3 says the songs of the temple shall be howlings on that day.

questions.question: Who does Amos 8:4 address as those who swallow up the needy?
options: Those who make the poor of the land to fail
The priests in the temple
The foreign nations
The kings of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Those who make the poor of the land to fail
questions.explanation: Amos 8:4 speaks to those who swallow up the needy and make the poor of the land to fail.

questions.question: According to Amos 8:5, what dishonest practice did merchants engage in?
options: Making the ephah small and the shekel great
Stealing from the temple
Refusing to sell wheat
Charging no interest
questions.correctAnswer: Making the ephah small and the shekel great
questions.explanation: Amos 8:5 describes merchants making the ephah small and the shekel great, falsifying balances by deceit.

questions.question: What will the Lord never forget, according to Amos 8:7?
options: Any of their works
The prayers of the righteous
The songs of the temple
The sacrifices offered
questions.correctAnswer: Any of their works
questions.explanation: Amos 8:7 states that the LORD swore He will never forget any of their works.

questions.question: What natural disaster is used as a metaphor in Amos 8:8 to describe what will happen to the land?
options: It shall rise up wholly as a flood
It shall burn like fire
It shall be shaken by an earthquake
It shall be covered with darkness
questions.correctAnswer: It shall rise up wholly as a flood
questions.explanation: Amos 8:8 uses the metaphor of the land rising up as a flood and being cast out and drowned.

questions.question: What unusual event does God say He will cause in Amos 8:9?
options: The sun to go down at noon
The moon to shine at noon
The rain to stop forever
The sea to dry up
questions.correctAnswer: The sun to go down at noon
questions.explanation: Amos 8:9 says the Lord will cause the sun to go down at noon and darken the earth in the clear day.

questions.question: According to Amos 8:10, what will happen to feasts and songs?
options: Feasts will be turned into mourning and songs into lamentation
Feasts will be joyful and songs will praise God
Feasts will be forgotten and songs will cease
Feasts will continue as usual and songs will be silent
questions.correctAnswer: Feasts will be turned into mourning and songs into lamentation
questions.explanation: Amos 8:10 states that feasts will become mourning and songs will turn into lamentation.

questions.question: What kind of famine does the Lord say He will send in Amos 8:11?
options: A famine of hearing the words of the LORD
A famine of bread
A famine of water
A famine of livestock
questions.correctAnswer: A famine of hearing the words of the LORD
questions.explanation: Amos 8:11 explains that the famine will not be of bread or water but of hearing the words of the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 8:12 says that people will find the word of the LORD easily when they seek it.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 8:12 states that people will run to seek the word of the LORD but shall not find it.

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 8:13, young men and fair virgins will faint for thirst in that day.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 8:13 says the fair virgins and young men shall faint for thirst in that day.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 8:14 says those who swear by the sin of Samaria will rise up again.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 8:14 states those who swear by the sin of Samaria shall fall and never rise again.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Amos 8:6: 'That we may buy the poor for silver, and the needy for a pair of ______;'
options: shoes
earrings
robes
hearts
questions.correctAnswer: shoes
questions.explanation: Amos 8:6 says 'That we may buy the poor for silver, and the needy for a pair of shoes.'

questions.question: According to Amos 8:10, what will come upon all loins and every head as a sign of mourning?
options: Sackcloth upon all loins and baldness upon every head
Crown of gold upon every head
Clothing of white upon all loins
Garlands of flowers upon every head
questions.correctAnswer: Sackcloth upon all loins and baldness upon every head
questions.explanation: Amos 8:10 describes sackcloth upon all loins and baldness upon every head as signs of mourning.

medium.title: Amos Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Amos Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Amos 8:4-6 teach us about honesty and integrity in our daily business practices?
options: We must not deceive others by falsifying measures or exploiting the poor
It is acceptable to delay payments to the needy for financial gain
Selling defective goods is a wise business strategy
Ignoring the needs of the poor is an acceptable practice
questions.correctAnswer: We must not deceive others by falsifying measures or exploiting the poor
questions.explanation: Amos 8:4-6 condemns those who make the ephah small and the shekel great, falsifying balances by deceit and exploiting the needy. This teaches the importance of honesty and fairness in business. It aligns with the biblical principle of integrity in all dealings.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God during difficult times. Based on Amos 8:2 and 8:7, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God will not forget the works of His people and His judgment is certain
God ignores the sins of His people and delays judgment indefinitely
Human efforts alone can save us from consequences
Judgment can be avoided by ignoring God's commands
questions.correctAnswer: God will not forget the works of His people and His judgment is certain
questions.explanation: Amos 8:2 speaks of the end coming upon Israel and God no longer passing by their sins, while 8:7 emphasizes that God swore by the excellency of Jacob never to forget their works. This assures believers that God is just and faithful, encouraging trust in His righteous judgment.

questions.question: How does the passage in Amos 8:11-12 teach us about the importance of spiritual discipline and devotion?
options: There will be a famine not of food but of hearing God's word, emphasizing the need to seek Him diligently
Physical hunger is the only real trial believers face
God's word will always be easy to find without effort
Spiritual discipline is optional in times of trial
questions.correctAnswer: There will be a famine not of food but of hearing God's word, emphasizing the need to seek Him diligently
questions.explanation: Amos 8:11-12 warns of a famine of hearing the words of the LORD, where people will search in vain. This highlights the critical importance of persistent spiritual devotion and discipline to remain connected to God's truth.

questions.question: According to Amos 8:9-10, how should believers respond to times of trial and mourning?
options: Recognize that God can turn times of joy into mourning to bring repentance and humility
Ignore mourning and pretend everything is fine
Avoid all sadness and maintain constant happiness
Solely focus on material comfort during trials
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that God can turn times of joy into mourning to bring repentance and humility
questions.explanation: Amos 8:9-10 describes God causing darkness at noon and turning feasts into mourning, which calls believers to humility and repentance during trials rather than ignoring or avoiding the pain.

questions.question: What does Amos 8:6 teach about the value of human beings from a biblical stewardship perspective?
options: People should not be bought or sold for trivial things; their dignity must be respected
It is acceptable to treat others as commodities for personal gain
Only material wealth matters in life
The poor have no value and can be disregarded
questions.correctAnswer: People should not be bought or sold for trivial things; their dignity must be respected
questions.explanation: Amos 8:6 condemns buying the poor for silver and selling refuse wheat, illustrating God's concern for the dignity and value of every person, which calls for stewardship marked by respect and care.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 8:13 teaches that even young and strong people will suffer thirst and faint without spiritual nourishment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 8:13 says fair virgins and young men will faint for thirst, symbolizing the deep spiritual need and deprivation when God's word is absent.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from Amos 8:5?
options: Do not eagerly wait to exploit opportunities for dishonest gain, but be content and honest
Always seek to increase wealth by any means
Ignoring rules about timing in business is acceptable
Dishonest manipulation of measures is a clever way to succeed
questions.correctAnswer: Do not eagerly wait to exploit opportunities for dishonest gain, but be content and honest
questions.explanation: Amos 8:5 criticizes those who impatiently wait for the new moon and sabbath to sell grain dishonestly, teaching believers to practice contentment and honesty rather than exploiting occasions for dishonest gain.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to take advantage of others financially. Based on Amos 8:4-6, what biblical principle should guide their decision?
options: Maintain integrity and avoid exploiting the needy or falsifying measurements
Use deceit to increase personal wealth
Ignore the needs of the poor for business success
Delay paying debts indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: Maintain integrity and avoid exploiting the needy or falsifying measurements
questions.explanation: Amos 8:4-6 condemns those who swallow up the needy and make dishonest business practices, instructing believers to act with honesty and fairness.

questions.question: According to Amos 8:8, what is God's response to injustice and exploitation in the land?
options: The land will tremble and mourn, rising up as a flood to bring judgment
God will ignore injustice forever
Injustice will be rewarded with prosperity
The land will remain peaceful despite wrongdoing
questions.correctAnswer: The land will tremble and mourn, rising up as a flood to bring judgment
questions.explanation: Amos 8:8 describes the land trembling and mourning due to injustice, symbolizing God's judgment against exploitation and wickedness.

questions.question: How does Amos 8:14 warn believers about false trust in idols or unreliable gods?
options: Those who swear by false gods will fall and not rise again
Idols provide true protection and salvation
Trusting in multiple gods is safe
God is indifferent to those who worship idols
questions.correctAnswer: Those who swear by false gods will fall and not rise again
questions.explanation: Amos 8:14 warns that those who swear by the sins of Samaria and gods of Dan and Beersheba will fall and never rise, emphasizing faithfulness to the true God.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 8:3 teaches that worship songs in the temple will become howlings and lamentations in the day of God's judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 8:3 states that the songs of the temple will turn into howlings and there will be many dead bodies, showing the seriousness of God's judgment.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and seeking God's word can be drawn from Amos 8:12?
options: We should seek God's word diligently now, lest there come a time we cannot find it
God's word is always guaranteed to be easily found without effort
Only physical needs deserve prayer attention
Seeking God is unnecessary if life is comfortable
questions.correctAnswer: We should seek God's word diligently now, lest there come a time we cannot find it
questions.explanation: Amos 8:12 describes people running to seek the word of the LORD and not finding it, emphasizing the urgency of diligent prayer and study before such famine occurs.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Amos 8:1 describes a vision given to Amos by the Lord involving a __________.
options: basket of summer fruit
field of wheat
river of fire
mountain of gold
questions.correctAnswer: basket of summer fruit
questions.explanation: Amos 8:1 states that the Lord showed Amos a basket of summer fruit, symbolizing the end of Israel's prosperity and the coming judgment.

questions.question: How does Amos 8:10 illustrate the connection between worship and repentance?
options: God turns feasts and songs into mourning and lamentation to bring people to repentance
Worship is only for celebration and never for sadness
Repentance is unrelated to worship practices
Festivals should always remain joyful regardless of sin
questions.correctAnswer: God turns feasts and songs into mourning and lamentation to bring people to repentance
questions.explanation: Amos 8:10 shows that God can transform joyful worship into mourning, signaling the need for repentance and humility in response to sin.

questions.question: Based on Amos 8:2 and 8:11, how does God communicate His judgment and call to faithfulness?
options: Through warnings of coming judgment and a famine of hearing His word to encourage seeking Him
By ignoring sin and allowing it to continue indefinitely
By only punishing physical needs, not spiritual ones
Through silence and inaction
questions.correctAnswer: Through warnings of coming judgment and a famine of hearing His word to encourage seeking Him
questions.explanation: Amos 8:2 warns of the end coming upon Israel, and 8:11 describes a famine of hearing God's word, both serving as calls to faithfulness and repentance.

hard.title: Amos Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Amos Chapter 8.

questions.question: In Amos 8:2, what is the significance of the 'basket of summer fruit' that the Lord shows Amos?
options: It symbolizes the ripeness and impending judgment upon Israel
It represents the abundance of God's blessings
It is a metaphor for the gathering of Israel's enemies
It illustrates the restoration of the land
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the ripeness and impending judgment upon Israel
questions.explanation: Amos 8:2 uses the image of a basket of summer fruit to foreshadow that the end has come upon Israel, indicating they are ripe for judgment.

questions.question: Amos 8:3 mentions that the songs of the temple will become what?
options: Howlings
Praises
Whispers
Silence
questions.correctAnswer: Howlings
questions.explanation: According to Amos 8:3, the songs of the temple will become howlings, symbolizing mourning and desolation instead of worship.

questions.question: What social injustice is condemned in Amos 8:4-6?
options: Exploiting the poor through dishonest scales and selling inferior goods
Refusing to pay temple taxes
Ignoring the plight of widows
Building altars for false gods
questions.correctAnswer: Exploiting the poor through dishonest scales and selling inferior goods
questions.explanation: Amos 8:4-6 condemns those who cheat the needy by manipulating weights and measures and selling worthless wheat, highlighting economic injustice.

questions.question: The oath God swears by 'the excellency of Jacob' in Amos 8:7 emphasizes what theme?
options: God's unforgetting justice towards Israel's deeds
God's mercy to Jacob
The superiority of Israel over other nations
The covenant of peace with Jacob
questions.correctAnswer: God's unforgetting justice towards Israel's deeds
questions.explanation: Amos 8:7 highlights God's solemn vow never to forget the works of Israel, underscoring divine justice in response to their actions.

questions.question: The imagery in Amos 8:8 of the land rising 'wholly as a flood' and drowning 'as by the flood of Egypt' alludes to which biblical event?
options: The plagues of Egypt
The parting of the Red Sea
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
The flood in the time of Noah
questions.correctAnswer: The flood in the time of Noah
questions.explanation: Amos 8:8's flood imagery recalls the Noahic flood as a symbol of total divine judgment and cleansing of the land.

questions.question: What is the prophetic significance of the sun going down at noon and the earth darkening in Amos 8:9?
options: It symbolizes sudden and unexpected judgment
It signifies a natural eclipse
It predicts the coming of the Messiah
It represents Israel's national restoration
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes sudden and unexpected judgment
questions.explanation: Amos 8:9 uses the striking image of midday darkness to illustrate the abrupt and devastating nature of God's judgment.

questions.question: According to Amos 8:10, what will happen to feasts and songs during the day of judgment?
options: Feasts will turn into mourning and songs into lamentation
Feasts and songs will be doubled in joy
Feasts will be ignored and songs will cease
Feasts will continue but songs will be silent
questions.correctAnswer: Feasts will turn into mourning and songs into lamentation
questions.explanation: Amos 8:10 declares that joyous celebrations will become times of mourning and sorrow during judgment.

questions.question: In Amos 8:11, the famine described is characterized by a lack of what?
options: Hearing the words of the LORD
Food and water
Peace and justice
Light and truth
questions.correctAnswer: Hearing the words of the LORD
questions.explanation: Amos 8:11 prophesies a famine not of physical sustenance but of spiritual nourishment through God's word.

questions.question: The phrase 'wander from sea to sea' in Amos 8:12 indicates what about the people's search for God's word?
options: They will seek God's word extensively but not find it
They will find God's word easily
They will abandon the search after a short time
They will receive God's word in abundance
questions.correctAnswer: They will seek God's word extensively but not find it
questions.explanation: Amos 8:12 describes a desperate and fruitless search for God's word across wide regions, emphasizing spiritual desolation.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the mourning described as 'the mourning of an only son' in Amos 8:10?
options: It signifies an intense and unique grief
It refers to a general sadness among the people
It symbolizes hope for future restoration
It indicates the mourning of priests only
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies an intense and unique grief
questions.explanation: Amos 8:10 uses this phrase to illustrate the profound depth and singularity of the sorrow that will overwhelm the people.

questions.question: Amos 8:6 mentions selling the poor for silver and the needy for a pair of shoes. What does this reveal about the economic conditions?
options: The poor were being exploited and devalued
The poor were generously supported
Barter was the main economic system
Silver was scarce and highly valued
questions.correctAnswer: The poor were being exploited and devalued
questions.explanation: Amos 8:6 criticizes the exploitation of vulnerable people, who were treated as commodities for minimal gain.

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 8:14, those who swear by the sin of Samaria and invoke the gods of Dan and Beersheba will fall and not rise again.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 8:14 pronounces a judgment on those who swear by idols, indicating their ultimate downfall and inability to recover.

questions.question: Amos 8:5 speaks about making the ephah small and the shekel great. What is the underlying issue addressed here?
options: Dishonest commercial practices undermining fairness
Religious rituals involving measurements
Agricultural laws for harvests
The standardization of weights and measures by the king
questions.correctAnswer: Dishonest commercial practices undermining fairness
questions.explanation: Amos 8:5 condemns fraudulent manipulation of weights and measures to cheat customers, a common injustice in ancient commerce.

questions.question: How does the theme of judgment in Amos 8 relate to the warnings found in the prophetic book of Jeremiah?
options: Both emphasize impending punishment for social injustice and idolatry
Both focus on the restoration of Israel without mention of judgment
Both highlight the building of a new temple
Both predict the coming of a peaceful kingdom without war
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize impending punishment for social injustice and idolatry
questions.explanation: Amos 8 and Jeremiah share themes of judgment due to Israel's social and religious failings, as seen in passages like Jeremiah 7.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Amos 8:8 when describing the land rising as a flood and being cast out as by the flood of Egypt?
options: Simile
Metaphor
Personification
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Amos 8:8 uses simile to compare the land's upheaval to a flood, enhancing the imagery of overwhelming judgment.

theological.title: Amos Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Amos Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What vision did the Lord show to Amos at the beginning of chapter 8?
options: A basket of summer fruit
A roaring lion
A burning coal
A flowing river
questions.correctAnswer: A basket of summer fruit
questions.explanation: Amos 8:1 records the Lord showing Amos a vision of a basket of summer fruit, symbolizing imminent judgment. This imagery aligns with prophetic visions in Joel 1:12 and Revelation 14:18-20, where ripe fruit represents judgment.

questions.question: According to Amos 8:2, what does the basket of summer fruit signify?
options: The end has come upon Israel
The harvest season is near
God's blessing upon the land
The beginning of a new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The end has come upon Israel
questions.explanation: Amos 8:2 states the Lord declares the end has come upon His people Israel, indicating judgment. This theme of divine judgment for covenant unfaithfulness is consistent with Deuteronomy 28:20 and Jeremiah 25:11.

questions.question: What will happen to the songs of the temple according to Amos 8:3?
options: They shall be howlings
They shall be joyful praises
They shall be silent
They shall be melodies of peace
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be howlings
questions.explanation: Amos 8:3 says the songs of the temple will become howlings, symbolizing mourning and desolation as a result of God's judgment. Similar transformations from joy to lamentation are recorded in Jeremiah 7:34 and Lamentations 2:8.

questions.question: Who does God address in Amos 8:4 for oppressing the needy?
options: Those who swallow up the needy
The priests and Levites
Foreign nations
The kings of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Those who swallow up the needy
questions.explanation: In Amos 8:4, God condemns those who exploit the poor and needy, emphasizing social injustice. This concern for the oppressed aligns with Isaiah 1:17 and Proverbs 31:8-9.

questions.question: What dishonest practices are condemned in Amos 8:5?
options: Falsifying balances and manipulating prices
Stealing from the temple treasury
Idolatrous sacrifices
Neglecting the Sabbath entirely
questions.correctAnswer: Falsifying balances and manipulating prices
questions.explanation: Amos 8:5 highlights deceitful commerce, such as falsifying measures and overcharging, violating God's commands in Leviticus 19:35-36 and Proverbs 11:1.

questions.question: What does Amos 8:6 say people are willing to buy and sell?
options: The poor for silver and the needy for a pair of shoes
Land and vineyards
Animals for sacrifices
Religious titles
questions.correctAnswer: The poor for silver and the needy for a pair of shoes
questions.explanation: Amos 8:6 condemns the commodification of human beings, reflecting a profound moral corruption. This is consistent with Exodus 22:21-24 and Isaiah 10:2-3 on oppression of the poor.

questions.question: By what does the LORD swear in Amos 8:7 to never forget the works of Israel?
options: By the excellency of Jacob
By the heavens and the earth
By His holy name
By the angels of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: By the excellency of Jacob
questions.explanation: Amos 8:7 shows God's solemn oath by the excellency of Jacob, underscoring His faithfulness and justice. This form of divine oath is echoed in Genesis 32:10 and Psalm 47:4.

questions.question: What consequence does Amos 8:8 describe for the land because of Israel's sins?
options: The land shall tremble and be cast out like the flood of Egypt
The land shall prosper and yield fruit
The land shall be covered in darkness
The land shall be given to foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: The land shall tremble and be cast out like the flood of Egypt
questions.explanation: Amos 8:8 uses the metaphor of a flood to describe the land's judgment, reminiscent of God's judgments in Exodus 14:21-22 and Isaiah 54:9, indicating overwhelming destruction.

questions.question: What unusual event involving the sun does God declare in Amos 8:9?
options: The sun will go down at noon and the earth will darken in clear day
The sun will shine seven times brighter
The sun will not rise for seven days
The sun will turn into blood
questions.correctAnswer: The sun will go down at noon and the earth will darken in clear day
questions.explanation: Amos 8:9 prophesies a miraculous darkening of the sun at noon, symbolizing divine judgment. This motif appears in Joel 2:31 and Matthew 27:45, emphasizing eschatological significance.

questions.question: How will God transform feasts and songs according to Amos 8:10?
options: Feasts will become mourning and songs will become lamentations
Feasts will be doubled and songs will be joyful
Feasts will be abolished and songs will cease
Feasts will be private and songs will be silent
questions.correctAnswer: Feasts will become mourning and songs will become lamentations
questions.explanation: Amos 8:10 states that celebrations will turn to sorrow as a result of judgment, reflecting the reversal of joy found in Jeremiah 7:34 and Zephaniah 1:15.

questions.question: What kind of famine does the Lord declare in Amos 8:11?
options: A famine of hearing the words of the LORD
A famine of bread and water
A famine of peace and justice
A famine of oil and wine
questions.correctAnswer: A famine of hearing the words of the LORD
questions.explanation: Amos 8:11 predicts a spiritual famine where God's word will be scarce, contrasting physical famine. This theme resonates with Hosea 4:6 and Matthew 4:4 about the necessity of God's word for life.

questions.question: What will people do in their search for the word of the LORD in Amos 8:12?
options: They shall wander from sea to sea and run to and fro but not find it
They shall gather eagerly and find abundance
They shall reject it and turn to idols
They shall receive it from foreign prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They shall wander from sea to sea and run to and fro but not find it
questions.explanation: Amos 8:12 describes people desperately searching for God's word but in vain, indicating divine withholding due to persistent rebellion, paralleling Isaiah 59:9 and Jeremiah 29:13.

questions.question: Who will faint for thirst according to Amos 8:13?
options: Fair virgins and young men
Kings and priests
Foreign merchants
Old men and children
questions.correctAnswer: Fair virgins and young men
questions.explanation: Amos 8:13 portrays the youth fainting for spiritual thirst, emphasizing the widespread impact of the spiritual famine. This imagery aligns with Isaiah 55:1-2 and John 4:13-14.

questions.question: What is the fate of those who swear by the sin of Samaria and the manner of Beersheba in Amos 8:14?
options: They shall fall and never rise again
They shall be forgiven upon repentance
They shall be exiled but return
They shall receive blessings
questions.correctAnswer: They shall fall and never rise again
questions.explanation: Amos 8:14 declares a final and irreversible judgment on those who adopt idolatrous practices, consistent with God's judgment on covenant breakers in Hosea 4:17 and Ezekiel 16:59.

questions.question: What theological theme is central to the entire Amos 8 chapter?
options: God's righteous judgment on social injustice and covenant unfaithfulness
The promise of restoration and blessing
The establishment of a new temple worship
The genealogy of Israel's kings
questions.correctAnswer: God's righteous judgment on social injustice and covenant unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Amos 8 focuses on God's justice against exploitation and idolatry, a consistent prophetic theme seen in Micah 6:8 and Isaiah 1:17, emphasizing God's holiness and moral demands.
